articles.headline: Nuclear Power Expansion in China Stirs Concerns
articles.snippet: China’s aggressive program of building new nuclear plants could cut carbon emissions, but experts worry that the pace may lead to safety shortcuts.
articles.abstract: China’s aggressive program of building new nuclear plants could cut carbon emissions, but experts worry that the pace may lead to safety shortcuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China  China is preparing to build three times as many nuclear power plants in the coming decade as the rest of the world combined, a breakneck pace with the potential to help slow global warming.

articles.headline: Iranian Dealings Lead to a Fine for Credit Suisse
articles.snippet: Credit Suisse is expected to pay a fine of $536 million to settle charges that it violated sanctions.
articles.abstract: Credit Suisse is expected to pay a fine of $536 million to settle charges that it violated sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Credit Suisse is expected to pay a fine of $536 million to settle accusations by the United States government and New York State authorities that it violated sanctions by helping Iran and other countries secretly funnel hundreds of millions of dollars through American banks, people involved in the negotiations said Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Claudio Gatti and John Eligon

articles.headline: Oral Roberts, Fiery Preacher, Dies at 91
articles.snippet: Mr. Roberts’s televised ministry attracted millions of followers and made him one of the most controversial religious leaders of the 20th century.
articles.abstract: Mr. Roberts’s televised ministry attracted millions of followers and made him one of the most controversial religious leaders of the 20th century.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oral Roberts, the Pentecostal evangelist whose televised faith-healing ministry attracted millions of followers worldwide and made him one of the most recognizable and controversial religious leaders of the 20th century, died Tuesday in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 91.

articles.headline: Music Business Heads Into Virtual World
articles.snippet: Apple’s purchase of the start-up Lala is bringing more attention to streaming music services as a replacement for songs on your computer.
articles.abstract: Apple’s purchase of the start-up Lala is bringing more attention to streaming music services as a replacement for songs on your computer.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  With its deal this month to buy the Web music service Lala, Apple may be pointing the way to the future of music.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: An Unwelcome Spotlight Falls on SAC Capital
articles.snippet: After a former SAC analyst was charged for activities occurring after he left the firm, a flurry of articles have tried to connect SAC with the investigation.
articles.abstract: After a former SAC analyst was charged for activities occurring after he left the firm, a flurry of articles have tried to connect SAC with the investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last two months, SAC Capital Advisors has turned into a $13 billion piñata.

articles.headline: As Goldman Thrives, Some Say an Ethos Has Faded
articles.snippet: Under Lloyd C. Blankfein’s leadership, Goldman Sachs now puts quick profits above all else, some executives say.
articles.abstract: Under Lloyd C. Blankfein’s leadership, Goldman Sachs now puts quick profits above all else, some executives say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just over a week ago, on the evening of Dec. 7, Lloyd C. Blankfein hosted a reunion of one of the most elite clubs in American finance: former partners of Goldman Sachs, the Wall Street giant he has led, with remarkable and controversial success, since 2006.

articles.headline: If Health Care Reform Fails, America’s Innovation Gap Will Grow
articles.snippet: The need for health coverage prevents many workers from finding new jobs or starting new companies, which suppresses economic growth.
articles.abstract: The need for health coverage prevents many workers from finding new jobs or starting new companies, which suppresses economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Greg Woock is the chief executive of Pinger, a fast-growing Silicon Valley company that makes iPhone applications. So Mr. Woock spends a fair amount of time interviewing job applicants. In almost every interview, he told me recently, the applicant asks about Pinger’s health insurance plan.

articles.headline: Never Listen to Céline? Radio Meter Begs to Differ
articles.snippet: By measuring what people listen to rather than what they report, a radio rating system is finding new winners.
articles.abstract: By measuring what people listen to rather than what they report, a radio rating system is finding new winners.
articles.lead_paragraph: American men have a naughty little secret. Sometimes, they like to relax with a little Céline Dion. Professed classical music fans have one, too: as it turns out, they don’t tune into classical radio nearly as much as they claim.

articles.headline: Magazines Get Ready for Tablets
articles.snippet: A new breed of electronic devices is expected in the months and years ahead, and publishers are already creating apps and planning to charge for their content.
articles.abstract: A new breed of electronic devices is expected in the months and years ahead, and publishers are already creating apps and planning to charge for their content.
articles.lead_paragraph: Magazine publishers are taking a mulligan.

articles.headline: Russians Buy Stake in Web Games
articles.snippet: Digital Sky Technologies, the Russian firm that invested more than $200 million in Facebook, is leading a group that is buying a $180 million stake in Zygna, a creator of online games.
articles.abstract: Digital Sky Technologies, the Russian firm that invested more than $200 million in Facebook, is leading a group that is buying a $180 million stake in Zygna, a creator of online games.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The Russian firm that invested more than $200 million in Facebook this year is making another bet on the United States Internet industry.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: China Hunts for Art Treasures in U.S. Museums
articles.snippet: A delegation scoured the Metropolitan Museum of Art last week for objects looted in 1860 from a palace in Beijing.
articles.abstract: A delegation scoured the Metropolitan Museum of Art last week for objects looted in 1860 from a palace in Beijing.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s “treasure hunting team” descended on the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York last week, and James C.Y. Watt, the patrician head of Asian art, braced for a confrontation.

articles.headline: F.T.C. Says Intel Stifles Competition
articles.snippet: The agency asserted the chip maker systematically prevented rivals from selling their products by blocking access to the market.
articles.abstract: The agency asserted the chip maker systematically prevented rivals from selling their products by blocking access to the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The muscular giants of the technology industry often seem to be one step ahead of antitrust regulators, who must rely on century-old laws and slow-moving courts. Technology markets, by contrast, operate according to the hurry-up clock of the Internet age.
